name: Torah - The Pentateuch | Jewish Sacred Texts

primarySources.theme: Covenant Renewal - Blessings, Curses, Moses' Death

summary: The Torah (also called the Pentateuch or Five Books of Moses) is the foundational scripture of Judaism. These five books - Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy - contain the creation narrative, patriarchal history, exodus from Egypt, Sinai covenant and law, wilderness wanderings, and Moses' final addresses. Matthew's Gospel is structured around five major discourses that deliberately mirror the Torah's fivefold structure, presenting Jesus as the new and greater Moses who gives authoritative interpretation of the Law.

keyPassages.text: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth
The LORD said to Abram, Go from your country... I will bless you
keyPassages.significance: Abrahamic covenant - Matthew's genealogy starts here

keyPassages.text: God spoke all these words: I am the LORD your God...
keyPassages.significance: Ten Commandments - Jesus interprets these in Sermon on Mount

keyPassages.text: You shall love your neighbor as yourself
Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God, the LORD is one. Love the LORD your God...
The LORD your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers
keyPassages.significance: Moses predicts the Prophet - fulfilled in Jesus

historicalContext: Traditional dating places Moses in 15th-13th century BCE. The Torah was transmitted orally and in writing through Israel's history, reaching final form by the time of Ezra (5th century BCE). By Jesus' time, the Torah was read in synagogues every Sabbath, with the entire Pentateuch completed in annual or triennial cycles.
structure: Five books corresponding to Matthew's five major discourses
influence: Foundation of Western civilization's ethical monotheism, legal traditions, and Sabbath concept. Matthew deliberately structures his Gospel with five discourses to parallel the Torah, presenting Jesus as the authoritative interpreter of Moses' Law.

matthewTorahParallel.description: Matthew structures his Gospel around five major discourses, deliberately mirroring the five books of Torah to present Jesus as the new Moses who gives authoritative interpretation of the Law

parallel_elements: Genesis: Creation narrative / Matthew: New creation in Christ
Genesis: Genealogy from Adam to Jacob / Matthew: Genealogy from Abraham to Jesus
Genesis: Beginning of covenant people / Matthew: Kingdom constitution given
Genesis: Blessing promised to nations / Matthew: Beatitudes - blessed are...

parallel_structure.torah_theme: Deliverance - Egypt, Law from Sinai, Tabernacle
parallel_elements: Exodus: Moses receives Law on Sinai / Matthew: Jesus gives Law on mountain (5:1)
Exodus: 40 days on mountain / Matthew: 40 days in wilderness temptation
Exodus: Israel through water (Red Sea) / Matthew: Jesus through water (baptism)
Exodus: Ten Commandments / Matthew: 'You have heard... but I say' (5:21-48)

parallel_structure.torah_theme: Holiness - Instructions for Priests and People
parallel_structure.matthew_discourse: Mission Discourse - Instructions for the Twelve
parallel_elements: Leviticus: Instructions for Levites/priests / Matthew: Instructions for apostles
Leviticus: How to approach God / Matthew: How to represent the Kingdom
Leviticus: Ritual requirements / Matthew: Mission requirements
Leviticus: Holiness code / Matthew: Worthy and unworthy reception (10:11-15)
Numbers: Israel grumbles in wilderness / Matthew: Parables of rejection (13:10-17)
Numbers: Rebellion and judgment / Matthew: Parables of judgment (weeds, net)
Numbers: Community regulations / Matthew: Church discipline (18:15-20)
Numbers: Leadership challenges / Matthew: Forgiveness among brothers (18:21-35)

parallel_structure.torah_theme: Covenant Renewal - Blessings and Curses, Moses' Final Words
parallel_elements: Deuteronomy: Covenant blessings and curses / Matthew: Woes against Pharisees (23)
Deuteronomy: Moses' farewell address / Matthew: Jesus' final public teaching
Deuteronomy: Future judgment and restoration / Matthew: End times prophecy (24-25)
Deuteronomy: Choose life or death / Matthew: Sheep and goats judgment (25:31-46)

matthewTorahParallel.formula_marking_discourse_end: Matthew marks each discourse ending with: 'When Jesus had finished these sayings...' (7:28, 11:1, 13:53, 19:1, 26:1)

fulfillment_not_abolition.text: Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them
fulfillment_not_abolition.significance: Jesus affirms Torah's continuing validity while providing authoritative interpretation

antitheses.description: Six 'You have heard... but I say' statements in Sermon on Mount (Matthew 5:21-48)
antitheses.pattern: Jesus does not contradict Torah but gives its fuller, heart-level meaning
antitheses.corpusQuery: Matthew 5 you have heard but I say

greater_righteousness.text: Unless your righteousness exceeds that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven
greater_righteousness.significance: Jesus calls for internalized obedience, not merely external conformity

metadata.focus: Torah-Matthew parallel structure and Jesus as authoritative interpreter of Law

description: The Torah (Pentateuch) comprises the five books of Moses - Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy. Matthew structures his Gospel with five major discourses deliberately mirroring this fivefold Torah structure, presenting Jesus as the new Moses who fulfills and authoritatively interprets the Law.
